column63: 1.2 BackgroundThe Space and Missile Systems Center (SMC), a subordinate unit of Air Force Space Command, develops, acquires, fields and sustains military space systems. SMCs mission is to deliver resilient and affordable space capabilities. As part of this mission, SMC develops, acquires and sustains space-enabled global communications capabilities for the US. SMC DFARR BAA is developing demonstration elements of a MILSATCOM protected tactical system to position the U.S. Government in respect to affordability, performance and timeliness for the acquisition of next generation protected communications in the FY20 or later timeframe. Protected, tactical MILSATCOM must be able to provide anti-jam and low probability of interception/detection/exploitation (LPI/LPD/LPE) communications in both contested and benign operational environments.In support of the DFARR BAA, this Protected Tactical COMSATCOM OTA Demonstration matures the integrated Research and Development technologies into a COMSATCOM emulation environment configured for a beyond line of sight, over-the-air (OTA) R&D demonstration.Space Systems/Loral, LLC (SSL) expertise will be leveraged to integrate available technology and advance legacy MILSATCOM system performance through technology insertion and rapid prototyping of the SMC modified legacy system.

column63: 1.1	Background The Remote Sensing Center (RSC) at the Naval Postgraduate School is a consortium of local schools and community research entities dedicated to strengthening Remote Sensing research and education.   Knowledge of RSC technical and mission requirements are key criteria for being able to perform analysis and trade studies for this effort. 1.2	Objective The objective is to perform analysis and trade studies on advanced materials, manufacturing processes and testing to enhance legacy and emerging communication systems and materials of interest to RSC needs. The trade studies shall be used to identify the most balanced future technical solutions among a set of viable solutions. It is a key tool in developing designs that meet requirements in the most cost-efficient manner possible. The studies shall consider tradeoffs among factors such as performance enhancements, manufacturability, and/or life cycle cost impacts.

column63: ScopeUS warfighting superiority is improved, in part, by virtue of improved defense systems.  In particular, this effort will focus on a technology upgrade to the existing piston engine for the SA-200 (medium-sized) VTOL UAS.  The original design of the vehicle has a 2 cyl / 2 stroke engine which has proven to be only marginally suitable for the desired flight duration and payload.  This effort will involve a conversion to a turbine heavy fuel engine, creating a viable platform for Naval missions; and rapid prototyping of the modified systems. An upgrade of the power plant from the piston engine to a suitable turbine engine will allow the use of Heavy Fuel, which is preferred for Navy operations as well as all other maritime uses. Integration of the Turbine engine advances SA-200 performance and also offers a number of other benefits including lower weight and less heat inside the aircraft.  . The vehicle is currently estimated to be at TRL (Technology readiness Level) -4.   At the completion of this project, the goal is to reach TRL-7.

column63: 1.1	BackgroundThe Air Force Life Cycle Management Center (AFLCMC) Rapid Capabilities Office (RCO) performs selected study, development and fielding activities tasked directly by the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology and Logistics, the Secretary of the Air Force, and the Chief of Staff of the Air Force. This effort directly supports efforts in the USCENTCOM AOR by allowing for integration of communications for newer and legacy platforms operating in the CENTCOM AOR at the appropriate classification level. 1.2	ObjectiveThe goal of this effort is to deliver new capabilities to legacy communication systems and new technology capabilities by providing system engineering and testing capabilities of cross domain solutions to the Air Force Ground Station Infrastructure .  The contractor shall develop, integrate, configure, install, deliver, and test solutions enabling these capabilities.

column58: BAE SYSTEMS UNMANNED AIRCRAFT PROGRAMS INC.
column63: This objective of this effort is to develop a procedure to recover unmanned air vehicles (UAVs) onto air vehicles.  The recovery mechanism will be unpowered and towed behind a manned platform but may contain an autopilot and actuators to maintain stable flight.  The methodology will optimize a robust moving Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) solution based on differential GPS (dGPS) that has previously been employed for ground-based recoveries.   Initially recovery of a small 15lbs UAV on to a moving ground vehicle will be used to demonstrate the capture and attachment mechanism before demonstrating recovery in flight.  All aspects of the work will be recorded on video. Completion of the full airborne testing is conditional on obtaining necessary safety approvals from FAA and/or DOD range safety. Therefore, tasks 7-10 will be considered objectives, but not requirements to successful completion of this effort.

column63: Program BackgroundThe Air Force Research Laboratorys Information Directorate (AFRL/RI) core competencies are used to improve US warfighting superiority via enhancements to voice and data communication systems, as well as improved intelligence gathering/processing techniques and systems used on the battlefield.  For commanders to be effective, decisions must be made using a process that leverages command, control, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (C2ISR) technologies to provide relevant and accurate information.Advanced Materials, Manufacturing and Testing Information Analysis Center (AMMTIAC) engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D) studies and analyses in the areas of materials, manufacturing and testing technologies.  AMMTIAC Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) shall focus on incorporating advanced materials into legacy, new and emerging communication technologies and on advanced manufacturing techniques and methods to enhance emerging DoD systems, subsystems and components.  AMMTIACs advanced material, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) expertise can be leveraged to integrate and advance legacy system performance through AMMT technology insertion and rapid prototyping of the AMMT modified legacy systems.Todays security threats to communication demand new approaches in managing and securing information and ensuring freedom of action in communication on and off the battlefield.  Lack of real-time communications and intelligence within squads and platoons impairs situational awareness, mobility and a commanders ability to command and move troops forward. To stay up-to-date with real-time intelligence  intelligence once only available from Tactical Operations Centers (TOCs) and Combat Operations Centers (COCs)  disconnected warfighters need robust, reliable, and efficient access to cloud services at the edge of the network and battlespace.Micro Cloud Servers (MCSs) will provide mobile data processing capability currently unavailable to adversarial forces, thereby ensuring dominance in the cyber fight. The MCS can integrate with Marine Corps intelligence and operations databases so service personnel can quickly and easily access and share critical intelligence  interpolating systems and eliminating stovepipes while on the move. Geospatial Terrain Data, Combat Data, Operational Reporting, Full Motion Video (FMV), Targeting Data, Red & Blue Force Tracking Data, Open Source Intelligence (OSINT), ISR Data systems can all benefit from the MCS real-time data processing, cloud storage, and secure hardware. A technology currently unavailable to mobile warfighters, the MCS will allow users to collect, process, and store classified data at the edge.  Secure, compact, ruggedized, and easy to reconfigure and relocate, the MCS can be used in command centers, vehicles, or carried by Marines in remote areas where backhaul communications are unavailable. The MCS can serve many mobile devices simultaneously. This will allow commanders and squad members connected to the network to communicate and share information, making mission critical data virtually available to authorized users anywhere in the world at any time. 3	ScopeThe subcontractor shall deliver a series of reports on engineering and security studies, services, and analysis for an MCS capability.

column63: 2	Program BackgroundAMMTIAC engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D) studies and analyses in the areas of advanced materials, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) technologies.  Specific to this effort is the advancement of AMMT to support AFRL/RIT mission parameters for persistent communications.  The AFRL/RIT focus is on emerging system and component technologies to enhance the utility and survivability of connected and networked Air Force Systems, such as the sensors connected to an MQ-1 Predator or MQ-9 Reaper feeding data to a Defense Common Ground System (DCGS) station.  This focus includes the engineering activities intended to prevent or deny exploitation of essential or critical technologies and components of these systems.  The Naval Postgraduate School (NPS) Remote Sensing Center (RSC) has partnered with AFRL/RIT to respond to specialized program, operational, technical, and security needs within the Special Compartment Information (SCI), Special Access Program (SAP), and Alternative and Compensatory Control Measures (ACCM) environments.  NPS RSCNCR requires all security aspects to be seamlessly integrated with program and project management efforts executed within the organization.  3	ScopeThis effort is to provide expertise to the NPS RSC and AFRL/RIT programs utilizing AMMT tactics and techniques to navigate the eight (8) primary life cycle functions: System Enhancement, Manufacturing/Production/Construction, Training, Verification, Deployment, Operation, Support, and Disposal.

column63: 2 Program BackgroundAMMTIAC engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D)studies and analyses in the areas of advanced materials, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) technologies. Specificto this effort is the advancement of AMMT to support AFRL/RIT mission parameters for persistentcommunications. The AFRL/RIT focus is on emerging system and component technologies to enhance the utilityand survivability of connected and networked Air Force Systems, such as the sensors connected to an MQ-1Predator or MQ-9 Reaper feeding data to a Defense Common Ground System (DCGS) station. This focusincludes the engineering activities intended to prevent or deny exploitation of essential or critical technologies andcomponents of these systems.DARPA has teamed with AFRL/RIT to explore the feasibility of small unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) airbornelaunch and recovery approaches for providing distributed airborne capabilities (DAC) from existing air platforms.The agency envisions a large aircraft that, with minimal modification, could launch and recover multiple smallunmanned systems from a standoff distance. It is postulated that there is a useful trade space in terms of launchplatforms; recovery platforms; recovery techniques; the number of UAS employed; the size (and cost) of the UAS;UAS speed, range, and endurance; UAS propulsion; UAS survivability; payload types; and operational concepts.3 ScopeThis objective of this effort is to define and analyze the range of possible DAC missions and systems solutions,develop a conceptual design that illustrates feasibility and potential breakthrough capabilities, and provide planninginformation to support a new DARPA prototype demonstration program.

column63: 1.1 Scope The PACOM Review Board (PRB) Support effort shall provide analytical, technical, and knowledge based professional support to USPACOM from Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) who possess operational, acquisition, requirements, research and development (R&D) technology, security, planning, and policy experience in systems/capabilities that are integral components to USPACOMs planning and requirements processes. 1.2 Background The Remote Sensing Center (RSC) at the Naval Postgraduate School (NPS) is dedicated to strengthening Remote Sensing research and education. NPS and the Department of the Navy (DON) foster and encourage a program of relevant and meritorious research. RSC requires an understanding of DON emerging requirements for advanced materials, manufacturing processes and testing (AMMT) to enhance legacy and emerging communications systems. The United States Pacific Command (USPACOM) is a Unified Combatant Command of the United States armed forces responsible for the Pacific Ocean area. The U.S. Pacific Command mission is to promote security and peaceful development in the Asia-Pacific region by deterring aggression, advancing regional security cooperation, responding to crises, and fighting to win. The main combat power of USPACOM is formed by U.S. Army Pacific, Marine Forces Pacific, U.S

column63: The AFRL/RIT focus is on emerging system and component technologies to enhance the utility and survivability of connected and networked Air Force Systems.  This focus includes the engineering activities intended to prevent or deny exploitation of essential or critical technologies and components of these systems in support of the war on terror.Among AFRLs partners in the war on terror is US Cyber Command (CYBERCOM) whose focus is to identify and eliminate terror cells worldwide; develop and deliver capabilities to DoD components through rapid research and development, advanced studies and technical innovation.   Their mission overlaps with AFRLs R&D activities to rapidly disseminate information using cutting-edge assets to achieve secure, assured and persistent communications.Additionally, AFRL has partnered in the war on terror with the Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC) whose focus is to identify and eliminate terror cells worldwide; develop and deliver capabilities to DoD components through rapid research and development, advanced studies and technical innovation.  Their mission overlaps with AFRLs R&D activities to rapidly disseminate information using cutting-edge assets to achieve secure, assured and persistent communications.1.2	ScopeThe Scope of this effort is to provide Subject Matter Expert (SME) support per the classified addendum.

column63: AFRL/RI strives to advance the understanding of non-kinetic effects on traditional weapon systems and the supporting systems and technologies through the use of test and evaluation activities to incorporating defensive measures that are effective without being intrusive and that allow for expedient mission execution with the least amount of risk and cost exposure.  This includes providing warfighters with improved situational awareness for accurate weapons systems employment and impact awareness and/or automated Command and Control (C2) actions.The US Marine Corp (USMC) Marine Communications Squadron has a mission need to perform non-destructive evaluations (NDEs) for quality control, certification and accreditation (C&A) on manned and unmanned assets. These assets will be fully networked and collaborative in a tactical environment. 1.2	ScopeThe Scope of this effort is to provide support to the Marine Communications Squadron with engineering subject matter expertise (SME) for the Dynamically Adaptive Secure Compute Area Network (DASCAN) foundation for the USMC Advanced Simulation Combat Operations Trainer (ASCOT) integrated Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S) testing at Marine Aviation Weapons and Tactics Squadron One (MAWTS) Weapons and Tactics Instructor (WTI) exercises.

column63: 1.1	BackgroundThe Air Force A2 Intelligence Reconnaissance and Surveillance (ISR) mission is to enable decision advantage by providing and operating integrated, cross-domain ISR capabilities in concert with joint, national, and international partners. In support of this mission, the AFRL/RIT focus is on emerging system and component technologies to enhance the utility and survivability of connected and networked Air Force Systems, such as the sensors connected to an MQ-1 Predator or MQ-9 Reaper feeding data to a Defense Common Ground System (DCGS) station. SIRIS is a web-based situational awareness tool that enables global dynamic mission planning and execution for manned and unmanned platforms. SIRIS ingests real time data feeds and normalizes them for consumption by many systems and users. The SIRIS web application has historically been an intelligence personnel tool for providing the aircrew situational awareness and collaboration. This aircrew web application, which will be an integral part of the SIRIS Enterprise Solutions program, will provide visualization, collaboration, and workflows based on the air crews needs.AF A2 requires enhanced capabilities for AMMT to test and improve performance of ISR data integration and multi sensor data input resources.1.2	ObjectiveThe objective is to extend and test the tactical, aircrew User Interface within the SIRIS Enterprise Solutions to better support air crew needs for visualization, collaboration, and workflows, and in addition support SIRIS operations and maintenance.

column63: AMMTIAC engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D) studies and analyses in the areas of advanced materials, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) technologies.  Specific to this effort is the advancement of AMMT to support AFRL/RIT mission partners for persistent communications.  AFRL/RIT has partnered with Naval Postgraduate School Remote Sensing Center National Capitol Region (NPS RSC-NCR) to respond to specialized program, operational, and technical needs within mission partner environments, such as those found in Rapid Equipping Force (REF) and Joint Improvised-Threat Defeat Agency (JIDA) and Special Operations Command (SOCOM), and to provide key technologies and technical solutions that mitigate mission specific operational gaps.3	ScopeThis effort is to provide a subject matter expertise (SME) support by applying systems engineering, business analysis, technical evaluation and identify the Art of the Possible in mitigating technology gaps for RSC mission partners.

column63: 1.1	BackgroundThe Air Force Life Cycle Management Center (AFLCMC)  performs selected study, development and fielding activities tasked directly by the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology and Logistics, the Secretary of the Air Force, and the Chief of Staff of the Air Force. This effort directly supports efforts in the USCENTCOM AOR by allowing for integration of communications for newer and legacy platforms operating in the CENTCOM AOR at the appropriate classification level. 1.2	ObjectiveThe goal of this effort is to deliver new capabilities to legacy communication systems and new technology capabilities by providing system engineering and testing capabilities of cross domain solutions to the Air Force Ground Station Infrastructure.  The contractor shall develop, integrate, configure, install, deliver, and test solutions enabling these capabilities.

column63: AMMTIAC engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D)studies and analyses in the areas of advanced materials, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) technologies. Specificto this effort is the advancement of AMMT to support AFRL/RIT mission partners for persistent communications.AFRL/RIT has partnered with Naval Postgraduate School Remote Sensing Center National Capitol Region (NPSRSC-NCR) to respond to specialized program, operational, and technical needs within mission partnerenvironments and to provide evaluations of key technologies and technical solutions that mitigate mission specificoperational gaps.This effort is to provide a subject matter expertise (SME) support by with a whole-of-systems approach tounderstanding complex, interconnected national security vulnerabilities to identify and assess potential solutionsusing holistic (e.g., social-ecological system) resilience analysis concepts to assess threats and mitigation measures.

column63: AMMTIAC engineers provide technical expertise by performing advanced research and development (R&D) studies and analyses in the areas of advanced materials, manufacturing and testing (AMMT) technologies.  Specific to this effort is the advancement of AMMT to support AFRL/RIT mission parameters for persistent communications.  The AFRL/RIT focus is on emerging system and component technologies to enhance the utility and survivability of connected and networked Air Force Systems, such as the sensors connected to an MQ-1 Predator or MQ-9 Reaper feeding data to a Defense Common Ground System (DCGS) station.  This focus includes the engineering activities intended to prevent or deny exploitation of essential or critical technologies and components of these systems.  Air Force A2 ISR Innovations has teamed with AFRL/RIT to modify existing collection management (CM) and planning systems for the integration into operational workflows through automated means using open standards and architectures.  Specifically, to provide an architecture/framework called the Advanced CM Environment (ACME) that will facilitate machine-to-machine interfaces with designated CM systems.  Goals to be achieved with ACME include: optimized collection management planning, execution, and assessment; faster collection; increased efficiency; and customer transparency.3	ScopeThis objective of this subcontracted effort is to provide support to Alion with the interfacing of ACME with ISR STAKE and training on the operational use of ISR STAKE.
